publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">In-depth study of The Temptation revealed insights into Ensor’s creative process and his unconventional use of materials and drawing practices. As this video shows, rather than conceiving the composition at once on a single sheet of paper, Ensor drew with a variety of media on fifty-one individual sketchbook pages, developing the composition part by part, and later reworking the drawings to visually integrate the whole.

Click to watch the Technical Video.

The Temptation was damaged during the Battle of Belgium in 1940, as well as by environmental exposure over time. Conservation of the drawing—documented in this video—involved removing the individual sheets from their mount to reduce staining and repair tears. The sheets were then rejoined again in their original configuration.

Click to watch the Conservation Video.

Careful study of The Temptation’s construction and the way the sheets overlap suggest that Ensor mounted the drawing sheets from the center outward, initially using sketchbook pages cut in half and later incorporating complete folios. This video shows how the drawing might have evolved.

Click to watch the Assembly Video.
